p.s: The sixteen-year-old African-American girl Starr is the protagonist and narrator of the novel The Hate U Give by Angie Thomas, published in 2019.
In chapter 24 Starr tells her story as a first personfirst-person narrator.
She narrates the events how she experiences them and shows the raeder her unfiltered emotion.
Starr does not know the feelings and thoughts, of her surroundings, but with confronting the reader with her point of view and her inner-acting, she is authentic.

Starr makes use of slang, because she has lost the control or does not want to control her outward appearance anymore: I'm sick of this!Just like y'all think all of us are bad because of some people, we think the same about y'all.Until you give us a reason to think otherwise, we'll keep protesting. (ll. 55f).
The reader recognizes, how upset the narrator is.

Because Starr shows her experiencing her last moments with Khalil, the reader feels like he is on the same level as Starr: 'A hairbrush is not a gun' Khalil drops it into the side of the door.'A hairbrush is not a gun' He opens the door to ask if I'm okay.Then pow-pow - 'A hairbrush is not a gun!I scream as loud as I can, fist high in the air, tears in my eyes (ll. 18-23).

Starr also shows her inner attitude towards the police officers by using slang: 'You need to exit the street immediately', the cop says.You know what?Fuck it. (ll. 47f) The reader is able to understand the way she thinks and acts, because of knowing Starr's emotions and inner-acting.
To sum it up one can say that because of using the first narator the reader feels connected with her.
This is because of Starr narrating the events how she experiences them and showing her unfiltered emotions.
